story_title: Barley Yield Dynamics: Varietal Performance Across Sites and Years
story_subtitle: Analyzing Yield Variations, Site Suitability, and Annual Trends in 1930s Barley Cultivation

story_pieces.narration: Waseca yields the highest average (49.0), while Grand Rapids has the lowest (25.2), indicating strong site influence on productivity.
story_pieces.question: How do average yields vary by site, and which locations are most and least productive?

story_pieces.narration: Trebi (42.5) and No. 462 (42.3) show the highest average yields, while No. 475 (32.1) and Manchuria (32.7) are the lowest performers.
story_pieces.question: Which barley varieties achieve the highest and lowest average yields across all sites and years?

story_pieces.narration: Yields dropped significantly in 1932, with average falling from 38.5 to 31.4, an 18.4% decrease, affecting all varieties and sites.
story_pieces.question: How did yields change between 1931 and 1932, and was the decline consistent across all varieties?
story_pieces.visualization: grouped bar chart (year vs. average yield per variety)

story_pieces.narration: No. 462 at Waseca in 1931 achieved the highest single yield (65.8), while No. 475 at Grand Rapids in 1932 had the lowest (15.2).
story_pieces.question: What are the extreme yield values, and under which variety-site-year conditions did they occur?
story_pieces.visualization: scatter plot (yield values with variety/site/year labels for outliers)

story_pieces.narration: Wisconsin No. 38 shows a yield decline of 12.7% year-over-year, while Glabron dropped 26.5%, indicating varietal resilience differences.
story_pieces.question: Which varieties were most and least affected by the yield drop from 1931 to 1932?
story_pieces.visualization: line chart (year vs. yield for each variety)
